1.-1: Enter Theseus, Hippolyta, Philostrate and Attendants.

1.speaker: THESEUS.
1.line: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour

2.speaker: THESEUS.
2.line: Draws on apace; four happy days bring in

3.speaker: THESEUS.
3.line: Another moon; but oh, methinks, how slow

4.speaker: THESEUS.
4.line: This old moon wanes! She lingers my desires,

5.speaker: THESEUS.
5.line: Like to a step-dame or a dowager,

6.speaker: THESEUS.
6.line: Long withering out a young man’s revenue.

7.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
7.line: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night;

8.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
8.line: Four nights will quickly dream away the time;

9.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
9.line: And then the moon, like to a silver bow

10.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
10.line: New bent in heaven, shall behold the night

13.speaker: THESEUS.
13.line: Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments;

14.speaker: THESEUS.
14.line: Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth;

16.speaker: THESEUS.
16.line: The pale companion is not for our pomp.

17.speaker: THESEUS.
17.line: Hippolyta, I woo’d thee with my sword,

18.speaker: THESEUS.
18.line: And won thy love doing thee injuries;

19.speaker: THESEUS.
19.line: But I will wed thee in another key,

20.speaker: THESEUS.
20.line: With pomp, with triumph, and with revelling.

1.-3: Enter Egeus, Hermia, Lysander and Demetrius.

21.speaker: EGEUS.
21.line: Happy be Theseus, our renownèd Duke!

22.speaker: THESEUS.
22.line: Thanks, good Egeus. What’s the news with thee?

23.speaker: EGEUS.
23.line: Full of vexation come I, with complaint

24.speaker: EGEUS.
24.line: Against my child, my daughter Hermia.

25.speaker: EGEUS.
25.line: Stand forth, Demetrius. My noble lord,

26.speaker: EGEUS.
26.line: This man hath my consent to marry her.

27.speaker: EGEUS.
27.line: Stand forth, Lysander. And, my gracious Duke,

28.speaker: EGEUS.
28.line: This man hath bewitch’d the bosom of my child.

29.speaker: EGEUS.
29.line: Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,

30.speaker: EGEUS.
30.line: And interchang’d love-tokens with my child.

31.speaker: EGEUS.
31.line: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung,

32.speaker: EGEUS.
32.line: With feigning voice, verses of feigning love;

33.speaker: EGEUS.
33.line: And stol’n the impression of her fantasy

34.speaker: EGEUS.
34.line: With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gauds, conceits,

36.speaker: EGEUS.
36.line: Of strong prevailment in unharden’d youth)

37.speaker: EGEUS.
37.line: With cunning hast thou filch’d my daughter’s heart,

38.speaker: EGEUS.
38.line: Turn’d her obedience (which is due to me)

39.speaker: EGEUS.
39.line: To stubborn harshness. And, my gracious Duke,

40.speaker: EGEUS.
40.line: Be it so she will not here before your grace

42.speaker: EGEUS.
42.line: I beg the ancient privilege of Athens:

43.speaker: EGEUS.
43.line: As she is mine I may dispose of her;

44.speaker: EGEUS.
44.line: Which shall be either to this gentleman

45.speaker: EGEUS.
45.line: Or to her death, according to our law

47.speaker: THESEUS.
47.line: What say you, Hermia? Be advis’d, fair maid.

48.speaker: THESEUS.
48.line: To you your father should be as a god;

49.speaker: THESEUS.
49.line: One that compos’d your beauties, yea, and one

50.speaker: THESEUS.
50.line: To whom you are but as a form in wax

51.speaker: THESEUS.
51.line: By him imprinted, and within his power

52.speaker: THESEUS.
52.line: To leave the figure, or disfigure it.

56.speaker: THESEUS.
56.line: But in this kind, wanting your father’s voice,

57.speaker: THESEUS.
57.line: The other must be held the worthier.

58.speaker: HERMIA.
58.line: I would my father look’d but with my eyes.

59.speaker: THESEUS.
59.line: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.

60.speaker: HERMIA.
60.line: I do entreat your Grace to pardon me.

61.speaker: HERMIA.
61.line: I know not by what power I am made bold,

62.speaker: HERMIA.
62.line: Nor how it may concern my modesty

63.speaker: HERMIA.
63.line: In such a presence here to plead my thoughts:

64.speaker: HERMIA.
64.line: But I beseech your Grace that I may know

65.speaker: HERMIA.
65.line: The worst that may befall me in this case,

66.speaker: HERMIA.
66.line: If I refuse to wed Demetrius.

67.speaker: THESEUS.
67.line: Either to die the death, or to abjure

68.speaker: THESEUS.
68.line: For ever the society of men.

69.speaker: THESEUS.
69.line: Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires,

70.speaker: THESEUS.
70.line: Know of your youth, examine well your blood,

71.speaker: THESEUS.
71.line: Whether, if you yield not to your father’s choice,

72.speaker: THESEUS.
72.line: You can endure the livery of a nun,

73.speaker: THESEUS.
73.line: For aye to be in shady cloister mew’d,

74.speaker: THESEUS.
74.line: To live a barren sister all your life,

75.speaker: THESEUS.
75.line: Chanting faint hymns to the cold fruitless moon.

76.speaker: THESEUS.
76.line: Thrice-blessèd they that master so their blood

78.speaker: THESEUS.
78.line: But earthlier happy is the rose distill’d

79.speaker: THESEUS.
79.line: Than that which, withering on the virgin thorn,

80.speaker: THESEUS.
80.line: Grows, lives, and dies, in single blessedness.

81.speaker: HERMIA.
81.line: So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord,

82.speaker: HERMIA.
82.line: Ere I will yield my virgin patent up

83.speaker: HERMIA.
83.line: Unto his lordship, whose unwishèd yoke

84.speaker: HERMIA.
84.line: My soul consents not to give sovereignty.

85.speaker: THESEUS.
85.line: Take time to pause; and by the next new moon

86.speaker: THESEUS.
86.line: The sealing-day betwixt my love and me

88.speaker: THESEUS.
88.line: Upon that day either prepare to die

89.speaker: THESEUS.
89.line: For disobedience to your father’s will,

90.speaker: THESEUS.
90.line: Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would,

91.speaker: THESEUS.
91.line: Or on Diana’s altar to protest

92.speaker: THESEUS.
92.line: For aye austerity and single life.

93.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
93.line: Relent, sweet Hermia; and, Lysander, yield

94.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
94.line: Thy crazèd title to my certain right.

95.speaker: LYSANDER.
95.line: You have her father’s love, Demetrius.

96.speaker: LYSANDER.
96.line: Let me have Hermia’s. Do you marry him.

97.speaker: EGEUS.
97.line: Scornful Lysander, true, he hath my love;

98.speaker: EGEUS.
98.line: And what is mine my love shall render him;

99.speaker: EGEUS.
99.line: And she is mine, and all my right of her

101.speaker: LYSANDER.
101.line: I am, my lord, as well deriv’d as he,

102.speaker: LYSANDER.
102.line: As well possess’d; my love is more than his;

103.speaker: LYSANDER.
103.line: My fortunes every way as fairly rank’d,

104.speaker: LYSANDER.
104.line: If not with vantage, as Demetrius’;

105.speaker: LYSANDER.
105.line: And, which is more than all these boasts can be,

106.speaker: LYSANDER.
106.line: I am belov’d of beauteous Hermia.

107.speaker: LYSANDER.
107.line: Why should not I then prosecute my right?

108.speaker: LYSANDER.
108.line: Demetrius, I’ll avouch it to his head,

109.speaker: LYSANDER.
109.line: Made love to Nedar’s daughter, Helena,

110.speaker: LYSANDER.
110.line: And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, dotes,

112.speaker: LYSANDER.
112.line: Upon this spotted and inconstant man.

113.speaker: THESEUS.
113.line: I must confess that I have heard so much,

114.speaker: THESEUS.
114.line: And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof;

116.speaker: THESEUS.
116.line: My mind did lose it.—But, Demetrius, come,

117.speaker: THESEUS.
117.line: And come, Egeus; you shall go with me.

118.speaker: THESEUS.
118.line: I have some private schooling for you both.—

119.speaker: THESEUS.
119.line: For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself

120.speaker: THESEUS.
120.line: To fit your fancies to your father’s will,

121.speaker: THESEUS.
121.line: Or else the law of Athens yields you up

122.speaker: THESEUS.
122.line: (Which by no means we may extenuate)

123.speaker: THESEUS.
123.line: To death, or to a vow of single life.

124.speaker: THESEUS.
124.line: Come, my Hippolyta. What cheer, my love?

126.speaker: THESEUS.
126.line: I must employ you in some business

127.speaker: THESEUS.
127.line: Against our nuptial, and confer with you

128.speaker: THESEUS.
128.line: Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.

129.speaker: EGEUS.
129.line: With duty and desire we follow you.

130.speaker: LYSANDER.
130.line: How now, my love? Why is your cheek so pale?

131.speaker: LYSANDER.
131.line: How chance the roses there do fade so fast?

132.speaker: HERMIA.
132.line: Belike for want of rain, which I could well

133.speaker: HERMIA.
133.line: Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.

134.speaker: LYSANDER.
134.line: Ay me! For aught that I could ever read,

135.speaker: LYSANDER.
135.line: Could ever hear by tale or history,

136.speaker: LYSANDER.
136.line: The course of true love never did run smooth.

137.speaker: LYSANDER.
137.line: But either it was different in blood—

138.speaker: HERMIA.
138.line: O cross! Too high to be enthrall’d to low.

139.speaker: LYSANDER.
139.line: Or else misgraffèd in respect of years—

140.speaker: HERMIA.
140.line: O spite! Too old to be engag’d to young.

141.speaker: LYSANDER.
141.line: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends—

142.speaker: HERMIA.
142.line: O hell! to choose love by another’s eyes!

143.speaker: LYSANDER.
143.line: Or, if there were a sympathy in choice,

144.speaker: LYSANDER.
144.line: War, death, or sickness did lay siege to it,

145.speaker: LYSANDER.
145.line: Making it momentany as a sound,

146.speaker: LYSANDER.
146.line: Swift as a shadow, short as any dream,

147.speaker: LYSANDER.
147.line: Brief as the lightning in the collied night

148.speaker: LYSANDER.
148.line: That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and earth,

149.speaker: LYSANDER.
149.line: And, ere a man hath power to say, ‘Behold!’

150.speaker: LYSANDER.
150.line: The jaws of darkness do devour it up:

151.speaker: LYSANDER.
151.line: So quick bright things come to confusion.

152.speaker: HERMIA.
152.line: If then true lovers have ever cross’d,

153.speaker: HERMIA.
153.line: It stands as an edict in destiny.

154.speaker: HERMIA.
154.line: Then let us teach our trial patience,

155.speaker: HERMIA.
155.line: Because it is a customary cross,

156.speaker: HERMIA.
156.line: As due to love as thoughts and dreams and sighs,

157.speaker: HERMIA.
157.line: Wishes and tears, poor fancy’s followers.

158.speaker: LYSANDER.
158.line: A good persuasion; therefore, hear me, Hermia.

159.speaker: LYSANDER.
159.line: I have a widow aunt, a dowager

160.speaker: LYSANDER.
160.line: Of great revenue, and she hath no child.

161.speaker: LYSANDER.
161.line: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues,

162.speaker: LYSANDER.
162.line: And she respects me as her only son.

163.speaker: LYSANDER.
163.line: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee,

164.speaker: LYSANDER.
164.line: And to that place the sharp Athenian law

165.speaker: LYSANDER.
165.line: Cannot pursue us. If thou lovest me then,

166.speaker: LYSANDER.
166.line: Steal forth thy father’s house tomorrow night;

167.speaker: LYSANDER.
167.line: And in the wood, a league without the town

168.speaker: LYSANDER.
168.line: (Where I did meet thee once with Helena

169.speaker: LYSANDER.
169.line: To do observance to a morn of May),

170.speaker: LYSANDER.
170.line: There will I stay for thee.

172.speaker: HERMIA.
172.line: I swear to thee by Cupid’s strongest bow,

173.speaker: HERMIA.
173.line: By his best arrow with the golden head,

174.speaker: HERMIA.
174.line: By the simplicity of Venus’ doves,

175.speaker: HERMIA.
175.line: By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves,

176.speaker: HERMIA.
176.line: And by that fire which burn’d the Carthage queen

177.speaker: HERMIA.
177.line: When the false Trojan under sail was seen,

178.speaker: HERMIA.
178.line: By all the vows that ever men have broke

179.speaker: HERMIA.
179.line: (In number more than ever women spoke),

180.speaker: HERMIA.
180.line: In that same place thou hast appointed me,

181.speaker: HERMIA.
181.line: Tomorrow truly will I meet with thee.

182.speaker: LYSANDER.
182.line: Keep promise, love. Look, here comes Helena.

183.speaker: HERMIA.
183.line: God speed fair Helena! Whither away?

184.speaker: HELENA.
184.line: Call you me fair? That fair again unsay.

185.speaker: HELENA.
185.line: Demetrius loves your fair. O happy fair!

186.speaker: HELENA.
186.line: Your eyes are lode-stars and your tongue’s sweet air

187.speaker: HELENA.
187.line: More tuneable than lark to shepherd’s ear,

188.speaker: HELENA.
188.line: When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.

189.speaker: HELENA.
189.line: Sickness is catching. O were favour so,

190.speaker: HELENA.
190.line: Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go.

191.speaker: HELENA.
191.line: My ear should catch your voice, my eye your eye,

192.speaker: HELENA.
192.line: My tongue should catch your tongue’s sweet melody.

193.speaker: HELENA.
193.line: Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated,

194.speaker: HELENA.
194.line: The rest I’d give to be to you translated.

195.speaker: HELENA.
195.line: O, teach me how you look, and with what art

196.speaker: HELENA.
196.line: You sway the motion of Demetrius’ heart!

197.speaker: HERMIA.
197.line: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.

198.speaker: HELENA.
198.line: O that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!

199.speaker: HERMIA.
199.line: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.

200.speaker: HELENA.
200.line: O that my prayers could such affection move!

201.speaker: HERMIA.
201.line: The more I hate, the more he follows me.

202.speaker: HELENA.
202.line: The more I love, the more he hateth me.

203.speaker: HERMIA.
203.line: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.

204.speaker: HELENA.
204.line: None but your beauty; would that fault were mine!

205.speaker: HERMIA.
205.line: Take comfort: he no more shall see my face;

206.speaker: HERMIA.
206.line: Lysander and myself will fly this place.

207.speaker: HERMIA.
207.line: Before the time I did Lysander see,

208.speaker: HERMIA.
208.line: Seem’d Athens as a paradise to me.

209.speaker: HERMIA.
209.line: O, then, what graces in my love do dwell,

210.speaker: HERMIA.
210.line: That he hath turn’d a heaven into hell!

211.speaker: LYSANDER.
211.line: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold:

212.speaker: LYSANDER.
212.line: Tomorrow night, when Phoebe doth behold

213.speaker: LYSANDER.
213.line: Her silver visage in the watery glass,

214.speaker: LYSANDER.
214.line: Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass

215.speaker: LYSANDER.
215.line: (A time that lovers’ flights doth still conceal),

216.speaker: LYSANDER.
216.line: Through Athens’ gates have we devis’d to steal.

217.speaker: HERMIA.
217.line: And in the wood where often you and I

218.speaker: HERMIA.
218.line: Upon faint primrose beds were wont to lie,

219.speaker: HERMIA.
219.line: Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet,

220.speaker: HERMIA.
220.line: There my Lysander and myself shall meet,

221.speaker: HERMIA.
221.line: And thence from Athens turn away our eyes,

222.speaker: HERMIA.
222.line: To seek new friends and stranger companies.

223.speaker: HERMIA.
223.line: Farewell, sweet playfellow. Pray thou for us,

224.speaker: HERMIA.
224.line: And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius!

225.speaker: HERMIA.
225.line: Keep word, Lysander. We must starve our sight

226.speaker: HERMIA.
226.line: From lovers’ food, till morrow deep midnight.

229.speaker: LYSANDER.
229.line: As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!

230.speaker: HELENA.
230.line: How happy some o’er other some can be!

231.speaker: HELENA.
231.line: Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.

232.speaker: HELENA.
232.line: But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so;

233.speaker: HELENA.
233.line: He will not know what all but he do know.

234.speaker: HELENA.
234.line: And as he errs, doting on Hermia’s eyes,

235.speaker: HELENA.
235.line: So I, admiring of his qualities.

236.speaker: HELENA.
236.line: Things base and vile, holding no quantity,

237.speaker: HELENA.
237.line: Love can transpose to form and dignity.

238.speaker: HELENA.
238.line: Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind;

239.speaker: HELENA.
239.line: And therefore is wing’d Cupid painted blind.

240.speaker: HELENA.
240.line: Nor hath love’s mind of any judgment taste.

241.speaker: HELENA.
241.line: Wings, and no eyes, figure unheedy haste.

242.speaker: HELENA.
242.line: And therefore is love said to be a child,

243.speaker: HELENA.
243.line: Because in choice he is so oft beguil’d.

244.speaker: HELENA.
244.line: As waggish boys in game themselves forswear,

245.speaker: HELENA.
245.line: So the boy Love is perjur’d everywhere.

246.speaker: HELENA.
246.line: For, ere Demetrius look’d on Hermia’s eyne,

247.speaker: HELENA.
247.line: He hail’d down oaths that he was only mine;

248.speaker: HELENA.
248.line: And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt,

249.speaker: HELENA.
249.line: So he dissolv’d, and showers of oaths did melt.

250.speaker: HELENA.
250.line: I will go tell him of fair Hermia’s flight.

251.speaker: HELENA.
251.line: Then to the wood will he tomorrow night

252.speaker: HELENA.
252.line: Pursue her; and for this intelligence

253.speaker: HELENA.
253.line: If I have thanks, it is a dear expense.

254.speaker: HELENA.
254.line: But herein mean I to enrich my pain,

255.speaker: HELENA.
255.line: To have his sight thither and back again.

2.-9: Enter Quince, Snug, Bottom, Flute, Snout  and Starveling.

257.speaker: BOTTOM.
257.line: You were best to call them generally, man by man, according to the

259.speaker: QUINCE.
259.line: Here is the scroll of every man’s name, which is thought fit through

260.speaker: QUINCE.
260.line: all Athens, to play in our interlude before the Duke and Duchess, on

262.speaker: BOTTOM.
262.line: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on; then read the

263.speaker: BOTTOM.
263.line: names of the actors; and so grow to a point.

264.speaker: QUINCE.
264.line: Marry, our play is _The most lamentable comedy and most cruel death of

266.speaker: BOTTOM.
266.line: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a merry. Now, good Peter

267.speaker: BOTTOM.
267.line: Quince, call forth your actors by the scroll. Masters, spread

269.speaker: QUINCE.
269.line: Answer, as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

270.speaker: BOTTOM.
270.line: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

271.speaker: QUINCE.
271.line: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

272.speaker: BOTTOM.
272.line: What is Pyramus—a lover, or a tyrant?

273.speaker: QUINCE.
273.line: A lover, that kills himself most gallantly for love.

274.speaker: BOTTOM.
274.line: That will ask some tears in the true performing of it. If I do it, let

275.speaker: BOTTOM.
275.line: the audience look to their eyes. I will move storms; I will condole in

276.speaker: BOTTOM.
276.line: some measure. To the rest—yet my chief humour is for a tyrant. I could

277.speaker: BOTTOM.
277.line: play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in, to make all split.

286.speaker: BOTTOM.
286.line: This was lofty. Now name the rest of the players. This is Ercles’ vein,

287.speaker: BOTTOM.
287.line: a tyrant’s vein; a lover is more condoling.

290.speaker: QUINCE.
290.line: Flute, you must take Thisbe on you.

291.speaker: FLUTE.
291.line: What is Thisbe? A wandering knight?

292.speaker: QUINCE.
292.line: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

293.speaker: FLUTE.
293.line: Nay, faith, let not me play a woman. I have a beard coming.

294.speaker: QUINCE.
294.line: That’s all one. You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small

296.speaker: BOTTOM.
296.line: And I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too. I’ll speak in a

297.speaker: BOTTOM.
297.line: monstrous little voice; ‘Thisne, Thisne!’—‘Ah, Pyramus, my lover dear!

298.speaker: BOTTOM.
298.line: thy Thisbe dear! and lady dear!’

299.speaker: QUINCE.
299.line: No, no, you must play Pyramus; and, Flute, you Thisbe.

303.speaker: QUINCE.
303.line: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisbe’s mother.

306.speaker: QUINCE.
306.line: You, Pyramus’ father; myself, Thisbe’s father;

307.speaker: QUINCE.
307.line: Snug, the joiner, you, the lion’s part. And, I hope here is a play

309.speaker: SNUG
309.line: Have you the lion’s part written? Pray you, if it be, give it me, for I

311.speaker: QUINCE.
311.line: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

312.speaker: BOTTOM.
312.line: Let me play the lion too. I will roar that I will do any man’s heart

313.speaker: BOTTOM.
313.line: good to hear me. I will roar that I will make the Duke say ‘Let him

314.speaker: BOTTOM.
314.line: roar again, let him roar again.’

315.speaker: QUINCE.
315.line: If you should do it too terribly, you would fright the Duchess and the

316.speaker: QUINCE.
316.line: ladies, that they would shriek; and that were enough to hang us all.

317.speaker: ALL
317.line: That would hang us every mother’s son.

318.speaker: BOTTOM.
318.line: I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out of their

319.speaker: BOTTOM.
319.line: wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us. But I will

320.speaker: BOTTOM.
320.line: aggravate my voice so, that I will roar you as gently as any sucking

321.speaker: BOTTOM.
321.line: dove; I will roar you an ’twere any nightingale.

322.speaker: QUINCE.
322.line: You can play no part but Pyramus, for Pyramus is a sweet-faced man; a

323.speaker: QUINCE.
323.line: proper man as one shall see in a summer’s day; a most lovely

324.speaker: QUINCE.
324.line: gentleman-like man. Therefore you must needs play Pyramus.

325.speaker: BOTTOM.
325.line: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best to play it in?

327.speaker: BOTTOM.
327.line: I will discharge it in either your straw-colour beard, your

328.speaker: BOTTOM.
328.line: orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your

330.speaker: QUINCE.
330.line: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and then you will play

331.speaker: QUINCE.
331.line: bare-faced. But, masters, here are your parts, and I am to entreat you,

332.speaker: QUINCE.
332.line: request you, and desire you, to con them by tomorrow night; and meet me

333.speaker: QUINCE.
333.line: in the palace wood, a mile without the town, by moonlight; there will

334.speaker: QUINCE.
334.line: we rehearse, for if we meet in the city, we shall be dogg’d with

335.speaker: QUINCE.
335.line: company, and our devices known. In the meantime I will draw a bill of

336.speaker: QUINCE.
336.line: properties, such as our play wants. I pray you fail me not.

337.speaker: BOTTOM.
337.line: We will meet, and there we may rehearse most obscenely and

338.speaker: BOTTOM.
338.line: courageously. Take pains, be perfect; adieu.

339.speaker: QUINCE.
339.line: At the Duke’s oak we meet.

1.-11: Enter a Fairy at one door, and Puck at another.

341.speaker: PUCK.
341.line: How now, spirit! Whither wander you?

348.speaker: FAIRY
348.line: And I serve the Fairy Queen,

349.speaker: FAIRY
349.line: To dew her orbs upon the green.

350.speaker: FAIRY
350.line: The cowslips tall her pensioners be,

351.speaker: FAIRY
351.line: In their gold coats spots you see;

353.speaker: FAIRY
353.line: In those freckles live their savours.

354.speaker: FAIRY
354.line: I must go seek some dew-drops here,

355.speaker: FAIRY
355.line: And hang a pearl in every cowslip’s ear.

356.speaker: FAIRY
356.line: Farewell, thou lob of spirits; I’ll be gone.

357.speaker: FAIRY
357.line: Our Queen and all her elves come here anon.

358.speaker: PUCK.
358.line: The King doth keep his revels here tonight;

359.speaker: PUCK.
359.line: Take heed the Queen come not within his sight,

360.speaker: PUCK.
360.line: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath,

361.speaker: PUCK.
361.line: Because that she, as her attendant, hath

362.speaker: PUCK.
362.line: A lovely boy, stol’n from an Indian king;

363.speaker: PUCK.
363.line: She never had so sweet a changeling.

364.speaker: PUCK.
364.line: And jealous Oberon would have the child

365.speaker: PUCK.
365.line: Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild:

366.speaker: PUCK.
366.line: But she perforce withholds the lovèd boy,

367.speaker: PUCK.
367.line: Crowns him with flowers, and makes him all her joy.

368.speaker: PUCK.
368.line: And now they never meet in grove or green,

369.speaker: PUCK.
369.line: By fountain clear, or spangled starlight sheen,

370.speaker: PUCK.
370.line: But they do square; that all their elves for fear

371.speaker: PUCK.
371.line: Creep into acorn cups, and hide them there.

372.speaker: FAIRY
372.line: Either I mistake your shape and making quite,

373.speaker: FAIRY
373.line: Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite

374.speaker: FAIRY
374.line: Call’d Robin Goodfellow. Are not you he

375.speaker: FAIRY
375.line: That frights the maidens of the villagery,

376.speaker: FAIRY
376.line: Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern,

377.speaker: FAIRY
377.line: And bootless make the breathless housewife churn,

378.speaker: FAIRY
378.line: And sometime make the drink to bear no barm,

379.speaker: FAIRY
379.line: Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?

380.speaker: FAIRY
380.line: Those that Hobgoblin call you, and sweet Puck,

381.speaker: FAIRY
381.line: You do their work, and they shall have good luck.

384.speaker: PUCK.
384.line: I am that merry wanderer of the night.

385.speaker: PUCK.
385.line: I jest to Oberon, and make him smile,

386.speaker: PUCK.
386.line: When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile,

387.speaker: PUCK.
387.line: Neighing in likeness of a filly foal;

388.speaker: PUCK.
388.line: And sometime lurk I in a gossip’s bowl

389.speaker: PUCK.
389.line: In very likeness of a roasted crab,

390.speaker: PUCK.
390.line: And, when she drinks, against her lips I bob,

391.speaker: PUCK.
391.line: And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.

392.speaker: PUCK.
392.line: The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale,

393.speaker: PUCK.
393.line: Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me;

394.speaker: PUCK.
394.line: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,

395.speaker: PUCK.
395.line: And ‘tailor’ cries, and falls into a cough;

396.speaker: PUCK.
396.line: And then the whole quire hold their hips and loffe

397.speaker: PUCK.
397.line: And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear

398.speaker: PUCK.
398.line: A merrier hour was never wasted there.

399.speaker: PUCK.
399.line: But room, fairy. Here comes Oberon.

400.speaker: FAIRY
400.line: And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!

1.-12: Enter Oberon at one door, with his Train, and Titania at another, with

402.speaker: OBERON.
402.line: Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.

403.speaker: TITANIA.
403.line: What, jealous Oberon! Fairies, skip hence;

404.speaker: TITANIA.
404.line: I have forsworn his bed and company.

405.speaker: OBERON.
405.line: Tarry, rash wanton; am not I thy lord?

406.speaker: TITANIA.
406.line: Then I must be thy lady; but I know

407.speaker: TITANIA.
407.line: When thou hast stol’n away from fairyland,

408.speaker: TITANIA.
408.line: And in the shape of Corin sat all day

409.speaker: TITANIA.
409.line: Playing on pipes of corn, and versing love

410.speaker: TITANIA.
410.line: To amorous Phillida. Why art thou here,

411.speaker: TITANIA.
411.line: Come from the farthest steep of India,

412.speaker: TITANIA.
412.line: But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon,

413.speaker: TITANIA.
413.line: Your buskin’d mistress and your warrior love,

414.speaker: TITANIA.
414.line: To Theseus must be wedded; and you come

415.speaker: TITANIA.
415.line: To give their bed joy and prosperity?

416.speaker: OBERON.
416.line: How canst thou thus, for shame, Titania,

417.speaker: OBERON.
417.line: Glance at my credit with Hippolyta,

418.speaker: OBERON.
418.line: Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?

419.speaker: OBERON.
419.line: Didst not thou lead him through the glimmering night

421.speaker: OBERON.
421.line: And make him with fair Aegles break his faith,

423.speaker: TITANIA.
423.line: These are the forgeries of jealousy:

424.speaker: TITANIA.
424.line: And never, since the middle summer’s spring,

425.speaker: TITANIA.
425.line: Met we on hill, in dale, forest, or mead,

426.speaker: TITANIA.
426.line: By pavèd fountain, or by rushy brook,

427.speaker: TITANIA.
427.line: Or on the beachèd margent of the sea,

428.speaker: TITANIA.
428.line: To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind,

429.speaker: TITANIA.
429.line: But with thy brawls thou hast disturb’d our sport.

430.speaker: TITANIA.
430.line: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,

431.speaker: TITANIA.
431.line: As in revenge, have suck’d up from the sea

432.speaker: TITANIA.
432.line: Contagious fogs; which, falling in the land,

433.speaker: TITANIA.
433.line: Hath every pelting river made so proud

434.speaker: TITANIA.
434.line: That they have overborne their continents.

435.speaker: TITANIA.
435.line: The ox hath therefore stretch’d his yoke in vain,

436.speaker: TITANIA.
436.line: The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn

437.speaker: TITANIA.
437.line: Hath rotted ere his youth attain’d a beard.

438.speaker: TITANIA.
438.line: The fold stands empty in the drownèd field,

439.speaker: TITANIA.
439.line: And crows are fatted with the murrion flock;

440.speaker: TITANIA.
440.line: The nine-men’s-morris is fill’d up with mud,

441.speaker: TITANIA.
441.line: And the quaint mazes in the wanton green,

442.speaker: TITANIA.
442.line: For lack of tread, are undistinguishable.

443.speaker: TITANIA.
443.line: The human mortals want their winter here.

444.speaker: TITANIA.
444.line: No night is now with hymn or carol blest.

445.speaker: TITANIA.
445.line: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,

446.speaker: TITANIA.
446.line: Pale in her anger, washes all the air,

448.speaker: TITANIA.
448.line: And thorough this distemperature we see

450.speaker: TITANIA.
450.line: Fall in the fresh lap of the crimson rose;

451.speaker: TITANIA.
451.line: And on old Hiems’ thin and icy crown

452.speaker: TITANIA.
452.line: An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds

453.speaker: TITANIA.
453.line: Is, as in mockery, set. The spring, the summer,

454.speaker: TITANIA.
454.line: The childing autumn, angry winter, change

455.speaker: TITANIA.
455.line: Their wonted liveries; and the mazed world,

456.speaker: TITANIA.
456.line: By their increase, now knows not which is which.

457.speaker: TITANIA.
457.line: And this same progeny of evils comes

458.speaker: TITANIA.
458.line: From our debate, from our dissension;

459.speaker: TITANIA.
459.line: We are their parents and original.

460.speaker: OBERON.
460.line: Do you amend it, then. It lies in you.

461.speaker: OBERON.
461.line: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?

462.speaker: OBERON.
462.line: I do but beg a little changeling boy

465.speaker: TITANIA.
465.line: The fairyland buys not the child of me.

466.speaker: TITANIA.
466.line: His mother was a vot’ress of my order,

467.speaker: TITANIA.
467.line: And in the spicèd Indian air, by night,

468.speaker: TITANIA.
468.line: Full often hath she gossip’d by my side;

469.speaker: TITANIA.
469.line: And sat with me on Neptune’s yellow sands,

470.speaker: TITANIA.
470.line: Marking th’ embarkèd traders on the flood,

471.speaker: TITANIA.
471.line: When we have laugh’d to see the sails conceive,

472.speaker: TITANIA.
472.line: And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;

473.speaker: TITANIA.
473.line: Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait

474.speaker: TITANIA.
474.line: Following (her womb then rich with my young squire),

475.speaker: TITANIA.
475.line: Would imitate, and sail upon the land,

476.speaker: TITANIA.
476.line: To fetch me trifles, and return again,

477.speaker: TITANIA.
477.line: As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.

478.speaker: TITANIA.
478.line: But she, being mortal, of that boy did die;

479.speaker: TITANIA.
479.line: And for her sake do I rear up her boy,

480.speaker: TITANIA.
480.line: And for her sake I will not part with him.

481.speaker: OBERON.
481.line: How long within this wood intend you stay?

483.speaker: TITANIA.
483.line: If you will patiently dance in our round,

484.speaker: TITANIA.
484.line: And see our moonlight revels, go with us;

485.speaker: TITANIA.
485.line: If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.

486.speaker: OBERON.
486.line: Give me that boy and I will go with thee.

487.speaker: TITANIA.
487.line: Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies, away.

488.speaker: TITANIA.
488.line: We shall chide downright if I longer stay.

489.speaker: OBERON.
489.line: Well, go thy way. Thou shalt not from this grove

490.speaker: OBERON.
490.line: Till I torment thee for this injury.—

491.speaker: OBERON.
491.line: My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememb’rest

492.speaker: OBERON.
492.line: Since once I sat upon a promontory,

493.speaker: OBERON.
493.line: And heard a mermaid on a dolphin’s back

494.speaker: OBERON.
494.line: Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath

495.speaker: OBERON.
495.line: That the rude sea grew civil at her song

496.speaker: OBERON.
496.line: And certain stars shot madly from their spheres

499.speaker: OBERON.
499.line: That very time I saw, (but thou couldst not),

500.speaker: OBERON.
500.line: Flying between the cold moon and the earth,

501.speaker: OBERON.
501.line: Cupid all arm’d: a certain aim he took

502.speaker: OBERON.
502.line: At a fair vestal, thronèd by the west,

503.speaker: OBERON.
503.line: And loos’d his love-shaft smartly from his bow

504.speaker: OBERON.
504.line: As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.

505.speaker: OBERON.
505.line: But I might see young Cupid’s fiery shaft

506.speaker: OBERON.
506.line: Quench’d in the chaste beams of the watery moon;

507.speaker: OBERON.
507.line: And the imperial votress passed on,

509.speaker: OBERON.
509.line: Yet mark’d I where the bolt of Cupid fell:

510.speaker: OBERON.
510.line: It fell upon a little western flower,

511.speaker: OBERON.
511.line: Before milk-white, now purple with love’s wound,

513.speaker: OBERON.
513.line: Fetch me that flower, the herb I showed thee once:

514.speaker: OBERON.
514.line: The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid

515.speaker: OBERON.
515.line: Will make or man or woman madly dote

516.speaker: OBERON.
516.line: Upon the next live creature that it sees.

517.speaker: OBERON.
517.line: Fetch me this herb, and be thou here again

518.speaker: OBERON.
518.line: Ere the leviathan can swim a league.

519.speaker: PUCK.
519.line: I’ll put a girdle round about the earth

522.speaker: OBERON.
522.line: I’ll watch Titania when she is asleep,

523.speaker: OBERON.
523.line: And drop the liquor of it in her eyes:

524.speaker: OBERON.
524.line: The next thing then she waking looks upon

525.speaker: OBERON.
525.line: (Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull,

526.speaker: OBERON.
526.line: On meddling monkey, or on busy ape)

527.speaker: OBERON.
527.line: She shall pursue it with the soul of love.

528.speaker: OBERON.
528.line: And ere I take this charm from off her sight

529.speaker: OBERON.
529.line: (As I can take it with another herb)

530.speaker: OBERON.
530.line: I’ll make her render up her page to me.

531.speaker: OBERON.
531.line: But who comes here? I am invisible;

532.speaker: OBERON.
532.line: And I will overhear their conference.

533.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
533.line: I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.

534.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
534.line: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?

535.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
535.line: The one I’ll slay, the other slayeth me.

536.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
536.line: Thou told’st me they were stol’n into this wood,

537.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
537.line: And here am I, and wode within this wood

538.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
538.line: Because I cannot meet with Hermia.

539.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
539.line: Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.

540.speaker: HELENA.
540.line: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant,

541.speaker: HELENA.
541.line: But yet you draw not iron, for my heart

542.speaker: HELENA.
542.line: Is true as steel. Leave you your power to draw,

543.speaker: HELENA.
543.line: And I shall have no power to follow you.

544.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
544.line: Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair?

545.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
545.line: Or rather do I not in plainest truth

546.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
546.line: Tell you I do not, nor I cannot love you?

547.speaker: HELENA.
547.line: And even for that do I love you the more.

548.speaker: HELENA.
548.line: I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,

549.speaker: HELENA.
549.line: The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.

550.speaker: HELENA.
550.line: Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me,

551.speaker: HELENA.
551.line: Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave,

552.speaker: HELENA.
552.line: Unworthy as I am, to follow you.

553.speaker: HELENA.
553.line: What worser place can I beg in your love,

554.speaker: HELENA.
554.line: (And yet a place of high respect with me)

555.speaker: HELENA.
555.line: Than to be usèd as you use your dog?

556.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
556.line: Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;

557.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
557.line: For I am sick when I do look on thee.

558.speaker: HELENA.
558.line: And I am sick when I look not on you.

559.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
559.line: You do impeach your modesty too much

560.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
560.line: To leave the city and commit yourself

561.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
561.line: Into the hands of one that loves you not,

562.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
562.line: To trust the opportunity of night

563.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
563.line: And the ill counsel of a desert place,

564.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
564.line: With the rich worth of your virginity.

565.speaker: HELENA.
565.line: Your virtue is my privilege: for that

566.speaker: HELENA.
566.line: It is not night when I do see your face,

567.speaker: HELENA.
567.line: Therefore I think I am not in the night;

568.speaker: HELENA.
568.line: Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company,

569.speaker: HELENA.
569.line: For you, in my respect, are all the world.

570.speaker: HELENA.
570.line: Then how can it be said I am alone

571.speaker: HELENA.
571.line: When all the world is here to look on me?

572.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
572.line: I’ll run from thee and hide me in the brakes,

573.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
573.line: And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.

574.speaker: HELENA.
574.line: The wildest hath not such a heart as you.

575.speaker: HELENA.
575.line: Run when you will, the story shall be chang’d;

576.speaker: HELENA.
576.line: Apollo flies, and Daphne holds the chase;

577.speaker: HELENA.
577.line: The dove pursues the griffin, the mild hind

578.speaker: HELENA.
578.line: Makes speed to catch the tiger. Bootless speed,

579.speaker: HELENA.
579.line: When cowardice pursues and valour flies!

580.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
580.line: I will not stay thy questions. Let me go,

581.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
581.line: Or if thou follow me, do not believe

582.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
582.line: But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.

583.speaker: HELENA.
583.line: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field,

584.speaker: HELENA.
584.line: You do me mischief. Fie, Demetrius!

585.speaker: HELENA.
585.line: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.

586.speaker: HELENA.
586.line: We cannot fight for love as men may do.

587.speaker: HELENA.
587.line: We should be woo’d, and were not made to woo.

588.speaker: HELENA.
588.line: I’ll follow thee, and make a heaven of hell,

589.speaker: HELENA.
589.line: To die upon the hand I love so well.

590.speaker: OBERON.
590.line: Fare thee well, nymph. Ere he do leave this grove,

591.speaker: OBERON.
591.line: Thou shalt fly him, and he shall seek thy love.

592.speaker: OBERON.
592.line: Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.

594.speaker: OBERON.
594.line: I pray thee give it me.

595.speaker: OBERON.
595.line: I know a bank where the wild thyme blows,

596.speaker: OBERON.
596.line: Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows,

598.speaker: OBERON.
598.line: With sweet musk-roses, and with eglantine.

599.speaker: OBERON.
599.line: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night,

600.speaker: OBERON.
600.line: Lull’d in these flowers with dances and delight;

601.speaker: OBERON.
601.line: And there the snake throws her enamell’d skin,

602.speaker: OBERON.
602.line: Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.

603.speaker: OBERON.
603.line: And with the juice of this I’ll streak her eyes,

604.speaker: OBERON.
604.line: And make her full of hateful fantasies.

605.speaker: OBERON.
605.line: Take thou some of it, and seek through this grove:

606.speaker: OBERON.
606.line: A sweet Athenian lady is in love

607.speaker: OBERON.
607.line: With a disdainful youth. Anoint his eyes;

608.speaker: OBERON.
608.line: But do it when the next thing he espies

609.speaker: OBERON.
609.line: May be the lady. Thou shalt know the man

610.speaker: OBERON.
610.line: By the Athenian garments he hath on.

611.speaker: OBERON.
611.line: Effect it with some care, that he may prove

612.speaker: OBERON.
612.line: More fond on her than she upon her love:

613.speaker: OBERON.
613.line: And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.

614.speaker: PUCK.
614.line: Fear not, my lord, your servant shall do so.

615.speaker: TITANIA.
615.line: Come, now a roundel and a fairy song;

616.speaker: TITANIA.
616.line: Then for the third part of a minute, hence;

617.speaker: TITANIA.
617.line: Some to kill cankers in the musk-rose buds;

618.speaker: TITANIA.
618.line: Some war with reremice for their leathern wings,

619.speaker: TITANIA.
619.line: To make my small elves coats; and some keep back

620.speaker: TITANIA.
620.line: The clamorous owl, that nightly hoots and wonders

621.speaker: TITANIA.
621.line: At our quaint spirits. Sing me now asleep;

622.speaker: TITANIA.
622.line: Then to your offices, and let me rest.

624.speaker: FIRST FAIRY.
624.line: You spotted snakes with double tongue,

626.speaker: FIRST FAIRY.
626.line: Newts and blind-worms do no wrong,

627.speaker: FIRST FAIRY.
627.line: Come not near our Fairy Queen:

630.speaker: CHORUS.
630.line: Lulla, lulla, lullaby; lulla, lulla, lullaby.

631.speaker: CHORUS.
631.line: Never harm, nor spell, nor charm,

637.speaker: FIRST FAIRY.
637.line: Worm nor snail do no offence.

639.speaker: SECOND FAIRY.
639.line: Hence away! Now all is well.

641.speaker: OBERON.
641.line: What thou seest when thou dost wake,

642.speaker: OBERON.
642.line: Do it for thy true love take;

643.speaker: OBERON.
643.line: Love and languish for his sake.

644.speaker: OBERON.
644.line: Be it ounce, or cat, or bear,

649.speaker: LYSANDER.
649.line: Fair love, you faint with wand’ring in the wood.

650.speaker: LYSANDER.

651.speaker: LYSANDER.
651.line: We’ll rest us, Hermia, if you think it good,

652.speaker: LYSANDER.
652.line: And tarry for the comfort of the day.

653.speaker: HERMIA.
653.line: Be it so, Lysander: find you out a bed,

654.speaker: HERMIA.
654.line: For I upon this bank will rest my head.

655.speaker: LYSANDER.
655.line: One turf shall serve as pillow for us both;

656.speaker: LYSANDER.
656.line: One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.

657.speaker: HERMIA.
657.line: Nay, good Lysander; for my sake, my dear,

658.speaker: HERMIA.
658.line: Lie further off yet, do not lie so near.

659.speaker: LYSANDER.
659.line: O take the sense, sweet, of my innocence!

660.speaker: LYSANDER.
660.line: Love takes the meaning in love’s conference.

661.speaker: LYSANDER.
661.line: I mean that my heart unto yours is knit,

662.speaker: LYSANDER.
662.line: So that but one heart we can make of it:

663.speaker: LYSANDER.
663.line: Two bosoms interchainèd with an oath,

664.speaker: LYSANDER.
664.line: So then two bosoms and a single troth.

665.speaker: LYSANDER.
665.line: Then by your side no bed-room me deny;

666.speaker: LYSANDER.
666.line: For lying so, Hermia, I do not lie.

668.speaker: HERMIA.
668.line: Now much beshrew my manners and my pride,

669.speaker: HERMIA.
669.line: If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied!

670.speaker: HERMIA.
670.line: But, gentle friend, for love and courtesy

671.speaker: HERMIA.
671.line: Lie further off, in human modesty,

672.speaker: HERMIA.
672.line: Such separation as may well be said

673.speaker: HERMIA.
673.line: Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid,

674.speaker: HERMIA.
674.line: So far be distant; and good night, sweet friend:

675.speaker: HERMIA.
675.line: Thy love ne’er alter till thy sweet life end!

676.speaker: LYSANDER.
676.line: Amen, amen, to that fair prayer say I;

677.speaker: LYSANDER.
677.line: And then end life when I end loyalty!

678.speaker: LYSANDER.
678.line: Here is my bed. Sleep give thee all his rest!

679.speaker: HERMIA.
679.line: With half that wish the wisher’s eyes be pressed!

682.speaker: PUCK.

683.line: This flower’s force in stirring love.

684.line: Night and silence! Who is here?

685.line: Weeds of Athens he doth wear:

686.line: This is he, my master said,

688.speaker: PUCK.
688.line: And here the maiden, sleeping sound,

689.speaker: PUCK.
689.line: On the dank and dirty ground.

690.speaker: PUCK.
690.line: Pretty soul, she durst not lie

692.line: Churl, upon thy eyes I throw

694.line: When thou wak’st let love forbid

698.speaker: HELENA.
698.line: Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.

699.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
699.line: I charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.

701.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
701.line: Stay, on thy peril; I alone will go.

702.line: O, I am out of breath in this fond chase!

703.speaker: HELENA.
703.line: The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.

704.speaker: HELENA.
704.line: Happy is Hermia, wheresoe’er she lies,

705.speaker: HELENA.
705.line: For she hath blessèd and attractive eyes.

706.speaker: HELENA.
706.line: How came her eyes so bright? Not with salt tears.

707.speaker: HELENA.

708.speaker: HELENA.
708.line: No, no, I am as ugly as a bear,

709.speaker: HELENA.
709.line: For beasts that meet me run away for fear:

711.speaker: HELENA.
711.line: Do, as a monster, fly my presence thus.

712.speaker: HELENA.
712.line: What wicked and dissembling glass of mine

714.speaker: HELENA.
714.line: But who is here? Lysander, on the ground!

715.speaker: HELENA.

716.speaker: HELENA.

719.speaker: LYSANDER.

729.line: The will of man is by his reason sway’d,

731.speaker: LYSANDER.
731.line: Things growing are not ripe until their season;

732.speaker: LYSANDER.

733.speaker: LYSANDER.

734.speaker: LYSANDER.

735.speaker: LYSANDER.

736.speaker: LYSANDER.

737.speaker: HELENA.
737.line: Wherefore was I to this keen mockery born?

738.speaker: HELENA.
738.line: When at your hands did I deserve this scorn?

739.speaker: HELENA.
739.line: Is’t not enough, is’t not enough, young man,

740.speaker: HELENA.
740.line: That I did never, no, nor never can

741.speaker: HELENA.
741.line: Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius’ eye,

742.speaker: HELENA.
742.line: But you must flout my insufficiency?

743.speaker: HELENA.
743.line: Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do,

744.speaker: HELENA.
744.line: In such disdainful manner me to woo.

745.speaker: HELENA.
745.line: But fare you well; perforce I must confess,

746.speaker: HELENA.
746.line: I thought you lord of more true gentleness.

747.speaker: HELENA.
747.line: O, that a lady of one man refus’d,

748.speaker: HELENA.

749.speaker: LYSANDER.
749.line: She sees not Hermia. Hermia, sleep thou there,

750.speaker: LYSANDER.
750.line: And never mayst thou come Lysander near!

751.speaker: LYSANDER.
751.line: For, as a surfeit of the sweetest things

752.speaker: LYSANDER.
752.line: The deepest loathing to the stomach brings;

753.speaker: LYSANDER.
753.line: Or as the heresies that men do leave

754.speaker: LYSANDER.
754.line: Are hated most of those they did deceive;

755.speaker: LYSANDER.
755.line: So thou, my surfeit and my heresy,

756.speaker: LYSANDER.
756.line: Of all be hated, but the most of me!

757.speaker: LYSANDER.
757.line: And, all my powers, address your love and might

758.speaker: LYSANDER.
758.line: To honour Helen, and to be her knight!

759.speaker: HERMIA.
759.line: [_Starting._] Help me, Lysander, help me! Do thy best

760.speaker: HERMIA.
760.line: To pluck this crawling serpent from my breast!

761.speaker: HERMIA.
761.line: Ay me, for pity! What a dream was here!

762.speaker: HERMIA.
762.line: Lysander, look how I do quake with fear.

763.speaker: HERMIA.
763.line: Methought a serpent eat my heart away,

764.speaker: HERMIA.
764.line: And you sat smiling at his cruel prey.

766.speaker: HERMIA.
766.line: What, out of hearing? Gone? No sound, no word?

767.speaker: HERMIA.
767.line: Alack, where are you? Speak, and if you hear;

768.speaker: HERMIA.
768.line: Speak, of all loves! I swoon almost with fear.

769.speaker: HERMIA.
769.line: No? Then I well perceive you are not nigh.

770.speaker: HERMIA.
770.line: Either death or you I’ll find immediately.

771.speaker: HERMIA.
771.line: The Queen of Fairies still lying asleep.

954.line: Were met together to rehearse a play

955.speaker: PUCK.
955.line: Intended for great Theseus’ nuptial day.

956.speaker: PUCK.
956.line: The shallowest thick-skin of that barren sort

957.speaker: PUCK.
957.line: Who Pyramus presented in their sport,

958.speaker: PUCK.
958.line: Forsook his scene and enter’d in a brake.

959.speaker: PUCK.
959.line: When I did him at this advantage take,

960.speaker: PUCK.
960.line: An ass’s nole I fixed on his head.

961.speaker: PUCK.
961.line: Anon, his Thisbe must be answerèd,

962.speaker: PUCK.
962.line: And forth my mimic comes. When they him spy,

963.speaker: PUCK.
963.line: As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye,

964.speaker: PUCK.
964.line: Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort,

965.speaker: PUCK.
965.line: Rising and cawing at the gun’s report,

966.speaker: PUCK.
966.line: Sever themselves and madly sweep the sky,

967.speaker: PUCK.
967.line: So at his sight away his fellows fly,

968.speaker: PUCK.
968.line: And at our stamp, here o’er and o’er one falls;

969.speaker: PUCK.
969.line: He murder cries, and help from Athens calls.

970.speaker: PUCK.
970.line: Their sense thus weak, lost with their fears, thus strong,

971.speaker: PUCK.
971.line: Made senseless things begin to do them wrong;

972.speaker: PUCK.
972.line: For briers and thorns at their apparel snatch;

973.speaker: PUCK.
973.line: Some sleeves, some hats, from yielders all things catch.

974.speaker: PUCK.
974.line: I led them on in this distracted fear,

975.speaker: PUCK.
975.line: And left sweet Pyramus translated there.

976.speaker: PUCK.
976.line: When in that moment, so it came to pass,

977.speaker: PUCK.
977.line: Titania wak’d, and straightway lov’d an ass.

978.speaker: OBERON.
978.line: This falls out better than I could devise.

979.speaker: OBERON.
979.line: But hast thou yet latch’d the Athenian’s eyes

980.speaker: OBERON.
980.line: With the love-juice, as I did bid thee do?

981.speaker: PUCK.
981.line: I took him sleeping—that is finish’d too—

982.speaker: PUCK.
982.line: And the Athenian woman by his side,

983.speaker: PUCK.
983.line: That, when he wak’d, of force she must be ey’d.

984.speaker: OBERON.
984.line: Stand close. This is the same Athenian.

985.speaker: PUCK.
985.line: This is the woman, but not this the man.

986.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
986.line: O why rebuke you him that loves you so?

987.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
987.line: Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.

988.speaker: HERMIA.
988.line: Now I but chide, but I should use thee worse,

989.speaker: HERMIA.
989.line: For thou, I fear, hast given me cause to curse.

990.speaker: HERMIA.
990.line: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep,

991.speaker: HERMIA.
991.line: Being o’er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep,

993.speaker: HERMIA.
993.line: The sun was not so true unto the day

994.speaker: HERMIA.
994.line: As he to me. Would he have stol’n away

995.speaker: HERMIA.
995.line: From sleeping Hermia? I’ll believe as soon

996.speaker: HERMIA.
996.line: This whole earth may be bor’d, and that the moon

997.speaker: HERMIA.
997.line: May through the centre creep and so displease

998.speaker: HERMIA.
998.line: Her brother’s noontide with th’ Antipodes.

999.speaker: HERMIA.
999.line: It cannot be but thou hast murder’d him.

1000.speaker: HERMIA.
1000.line: So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.

1001.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1001.line: So should the murder’d look, and so should I,

1002.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1002.line: Pierc’d through the heart with your stern cruelty.

1003.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1003.line: Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear,

1004.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1004.line: As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.

1005.speaker: HERMIA.
1005.line: What’s this to my Lysander? Where is he?

1006.speaker: HERMIA.
1006.line: Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?

1007.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1007.line: I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.

1008.speaker: HERMIA.
1008.line: Out, dog! Out, cur! Thou driv’st me past the bounds

1009.speaker: HERMIA.
1009.line: Of maiden’s patience. Hast thou slain him, then?

1010.speaker: HERMIA.
1010.line: Henceforth be never number’d among men!

1011.speaker: HERMIA.
1011.line: O once tell true; tell true, even for my sake!

1012.speaker: HERMIA.
1012.line: Durst thou have look’d upon him, being awake,

1013.speaker: HERMIA.
1013.line: And hast thou kill’d him sleeping? O brave touch!

1014.speaker: HERMIA.
1014.line: Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?

1015.speaker: HERMIA.
1015.line: An adder did it; for with doubler tongue

1016.speaker: HERMIA.
1016.line: Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.

1017.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1017.line: You spend your passion on a mispris’d mood:

1018.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1018.line: I am not guilty of Lysander’s blood;

1019.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1019.line: Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.

1020.speaker: HERMIA.
1020.line: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.

1021.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1021.line: And if I could, what should I get therefore?

1022.speaker: HERMIA.
1022.line: A privilege never to see me more.

1023.speaker: HERMIA.
1023.line: And from thy hated presence part I so:

1024.speaker: HERMIA.
1024.line: See me no more, whether he be dead or no.

1025.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1025.line: There is no following her in this fierce vein.

1026.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1026.line: Here, therefore, for a while I will remain.

1027.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1027.line: So sorrow’s heaviness doth heavier grow

1028.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1028.line: For debt that bankrupt sleep doth sorrow owe;

1029.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1029.line: Which now in some slight measure it will pay,

1030.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1030.line: If for his tender here I make some stay.

1031.speaker: OBERON.
1031.line: What hast thou done? Thou hast mistaken quite,

1032.speaker: OBERON.
1032.line: And laid the love-juice on some true-love’s sight.

1033.speaker: OBERON.
1033.line: Of thy misprision must perforce ensue

1034.speaker: OBERON.
1034.line: Some true love turn’d, and not a false turn’d true.

1035.speaker: PUCK.
1035.line: Then fate o’er-rules, that, one man holding troth,

1036.speaker: PUCK.
1036.line: A million fail, confounding oath on oath.

1037.speaker: OBERON.
1037.line: About the wood go swifter than the wind,

1038.speaker: OBERON.
1038.line: And Helena of Athens look thou find.

1039.speaker: OBERON.
1039.line: All fancy-sick she is, and pale of cheer

1040.speaker: OBERON.
1040.line: With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear.

1041.speaker: OBERON.
1041.line: By some illusion see thou bring her here;

1042.speaker: OBERON.
1042.line: I’ll charm his eyes against she do appear.

1043.speaker: PUCK.
1043.line: I go, I go; look how I go,

1044.speaker: PUCK.
1044.line: Swifter than arrow from the Tartar’s bow.

1047.speaker: OBERON.
1047.line: Sink in apple of his eye.

1048.speaker: OBERON.
1048.line: When his love he doth espy,

1050.speaker: OBERON.
1050.line: As the Venus of the sky.—

1051.speaker: OBERON.
1051.line: When thou wak’st, if she be by,

1055.speaker: PUCK.
1055.line: And the youth mistook by me,

1057.speaker: PUCK.
1057.line: Shall we their fond pageant see?

1058.speaker: PUCK.
1058.line: Lord, what fools these mortals be!

1059.speaker: OBERON.
1059.line: Stand aside. The noise they make

1061.speaker: PUCK.
1061.line: Then will two at once woo one.

1062.speaker: PUCK.
1062.line: That must needs be sport alone;

1063.speaker: PUCK.
1063.line: And those things do best please me

1065.speaker: LYSANDER.
1065.line: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn?

1066.speaker: LYSANDER.
1066.line: Scorn and derision never come in tears.

1067.speaker: LYSANDER.
1067.line: Look when I vow, I weep; and vows so born,

1068.speaker: LYSANDER.
1068.line: In their nativity all truth appears.

1069.speaker: LYSANDER.
1069.line: How can these things in me seem scorn to you,

1070.speaker: LYSANDER.
1070.line: Bearing the badge of faith, to prove them true?

1071.speaker: HELENA.
1071.line: You do advance your cunning more and more.

1072.speaker: HELENA.
1072.line: When truth kills truth, O devilish-holy fray!

1073.speaker: HELENA.
1073.line: These vows are Hermia’s: will you give her o’er?

1074.speaker: HELENA.
1074.line: Weigh oath with oath, and you will nothing weigh:

1075.speaker: HELENA.
1075.line: Your vows to her and me, put in two scales,

1076.speaker: HELENA.
1076.line: Will even weigh; and both as light as tales.

1077.speaker: LYSANDER.
1077.line: I had no judgment when to her I swore.

1078.speaker: HELENA.
1078.line: Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o’er.

1079.speaker: LYSANDER.
1079.line: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.

1080.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1080.line: [_Waking._] O Helen, goddess, nymph, perfect, divine!

1081.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1081.line: To what, my love, shall I compare thine eyne?

1082.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1082.line: Crystal is muddy. O how ripe in show

1083.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1083.line: Thy lips, those kissing cherries, tempting grow!

1084.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1084.line: That pure congealèd white, high Taurus’ snow,

1085.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1085.line: Fann’d with the eastern wind, turns to a crow

1086.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1086.line: When thou hold’st up thy hand. O, let me kiss

1087.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1087.line: This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!

1088.speaker: HELENA.
1088.line: O spite! O hell! I see you all are bent

1089.speaker: HELENA.
1089.line: To set against me for your merriment.

1090.speaker: HELENA.
1090.line: If you were civil, and knew courtesy,

1091.speaker: HELENA.
1091.line: You would not do me thus much injury.

1092.speaker: HELENA.
1092.line: Can you not hate me, as I know you do,

1093.speaker: HELENA.
1093.line: But you must join in souls to mock me too?

1094.speaker: HELENA.
1094.line: If you were men, as men you are in show,

1095.speaker: HELENA.
1095.line: You would not use a gentle lady so;

1096.speaker: HELENA.
1096.line: To vow, and swear, and superpraise my parts,

1097.speaker: HELENA.
1097.line: When I am sure you hate me with your hearts.

1098.speaker: HELENA.
1098.line: You both are rivals, and love Hermia;

1099.speaker: HELENA.
1099.line: And now both rivals, to mock Helena.

1100.speaker: HELENA.
1100.line: A trim exploit, a manly enterprise,

1101.speaker: HELENA.
1101.line: To conjure tears up in a poor maid’s eyes

1102.speaker: HELENA.
1102.line: With your derision! None of noble sort

1103.speaker: HELENA.
1103.line: Would so offend a virgin, and extort

1104.speaker: HELENA.
1104.line: A poor soul’s patience, all to make you sport.

1105.speaker: LYSANDER.
1105.line: You are unkind, Demetrius; be not so,

1106.speaker: LYSANDER.
1106.line: For you love Hermia; this you know I know.

1107.speaker: LYSANDER.
1107.line: And here, with all good will, with all my heart,

1108.speaker: LYSANDER.
1108.line: In Hermia’s love I yield you up my part;

1109.speaker: LYSANDER.
1109.line: And yours of Helena to me bequeath,

1110.speaker: LYSANDER.
1110.line: Whom I do love and will do till my death.

1111.speaker: HELENA.
1111.line: Never did mockers waste more idle breath.

1112.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1112.line: Lysander, keep thy Hermia; I will none.

1113.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1113.line: If e’er I lov’d her, all that love is gone.

1114.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1114.line: My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourn’d;

1115.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1115.line: And now to Helen is it home return’d,

1118.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1118.line: Disparage not the faith thou dost not know,

1119.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1119.line: Lest to thy peril thou aby it dear.

1120.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1120.line: Look where thy love comes; yonder is thy dear.

1121.speaker: HERMIA.
1121.line: Dark night, that from the eye his function takes,

1122.speaker: HERMIA.
1122.line: The ear more quick of apprehension makes;

1123.speaker: HERMIA.
1123.line: Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense,

1124.speaker: HERMIA.
1124.line: It pays the hearing double recompense.

1125.speaker: HERMIA.
1125.line: Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found;

1126.speaker: HERMIA.
1126.line: Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound.

1127.speaker: HERMIA.
1127.line: But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?

1128.speaker: LYSANDER.
1128.line: Why should he stay whom love doth press to go?

1129.speaker: HERMIA.
1129.line: What love could press Lysander from my side?

1130.speaker: LYSANDER.
1130.line: Lysander’s love, that would not let him bide,

1131.speaker: LYSANDER.
1131.line: Fair Helena, who more engilds the night

1132.speaker: LYSANDER.
1132.line: Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.

1133.speaker: LYSANDER.
1133.line: Why seek’st thou me? Could not this make thee know

1134.speaker: LYSANDER.
1134.line: The hate I bare thee made me leave thee so?

1135.speaker: HERMIA.
1135.line: You speak not as you think; it cannot be.

1136.speaker: HELENA.
1136.line: Lo, she is one of this confederacy!

1137.speaker: HELENA.
1137.line: Now I perceive they have conjoin’d all three

1138.speaker: HELENA.
1138.line: To fashion this false sport in spite of me.

1140.speaker: HELENA.
1140.line: Have you conspir’d, have you with these contriv’d,

1141.speaker: HELENA.
1141.line: To bait me with this foul derision?

1142.speaker: HELENA.
1142.line: Is all the counsel that we two have shar’d,

1143.speaker: HELENA.
1143.line: The sisters’ vows, the hours that we have spent,

1144.speaker: HELENA.
1144.line: When we have chid the hasty-footed time

1145.speaker: HELENA.
1145.line: For parting us—O, is all forgot?

1147.speaker: HELENA.
1147.line: We, Hermia, like two artificial gods,

1148.speaker: HELENA.
1148.line: Have with our needles created both one flower,

1149.speaker: HELENA.
1149.line: Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion,

1150.speaker: HELENA.
1150.line: Both warbling of one song, both in one key,

1151.speaker: HELENA.
1151.line: As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds,

1152.speaker: HELENA.
1152.line: Had been incorporate. So we grew together,

1153.speaker: HELENA.
1153.line: Like to a double cherry, seeming parted,

1154.speaker: HELENA.
1154.line: But yet a union in partition,

1155.speaker: HELENA.
1155.line: Two lovely berries moulded on one stem;

1156.speaker: HELENA.
1156.line: So, with two seeming bodies, but one heart;

1157.speaker: HELENA.
1157.line: Two of the first, like coats in heraldry,

1158.speaker: HELENA.
1158.line: Due but to one, and crownèd with one crest.

1159.speaker: HELENA.
1159.line: And will you rent our ancient love asunder,

1160.speaker: HELENA.
1160.line: To join with men in scorning your poor friend?

1161.speaker: HELENA.
1161.line: It is not friendly, ’tis not maidenly.

1162.speaker: HELENA.
1162.line: Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it,

1163.speaker: HELENA.
1163.line: Though I alone do feel the injury.

1164.speaker: HERMIA.
1164.line: I am amazèd at your passionate words:

1165.speaker: HERMIA.
1165.line: I scorn you not; it seems that you scorn me.

1166.speaker: HELENA.
1166.line: Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn,

1167.speaker: HELENA.
1167.line: To follow me, and praise my eyes and face?

1168.speaker: HELENA.
1168.line: And made your other love, Demetrius,

1169.speaker: HELENA.
1169.line: Who even but now did spurn me with his foot,

1170.speaker: HELENA.
1170.line: To call me goddess, nymph, divine and rare,

1171.speaker: HELENA.
1171.line: Precious, celestial? Wherefore speaks he this

1172.speaker: HELENA.
1172.line: To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander

1173.speaker: HELENA.
1173.line: Deny your love, so rich within his soul,

1175.speaker: HELENA.
1175.line: But by your setting on, by your consent?

1176.speaker: HELENA.
1176.line: What though I be not so in grace as you,

1177.speaker: HELENA.
1177.line: So hung upon with love, so fortunate,

1178.speaker: HELENA.
1178.line: But miserable most, to love unlov’d?

1179.speaker: HELENA.
1179.line: This you should pity rather than despise.

1180.speaker: HERMIA.
1180.line: I understand not what you mean by this.

1181.speaker: HELENA.
1181.line: Ay, do. Persever, counterfeit sad looks,

1182.speaker: HELENA.
1182.line: Make mouths upon me when I turn my back,

1183.speaker: HELENA.
1183.line: Wink each at other; hold the sweet jest up.

1184.speaker: HELENA.
1184.line: This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.

1185.speaker: HELENA.
1185.line: If you have any pity, grace, or manners,

1186.speaker: HELENA.
1186.line: You would not make me such an argument.

1187.speaker: HELENA.
1187.line: But fare ye well. ’Tis partly my own fault,

1188.speaker: HELENA.
1188.line: Which death, or absence, soon shall remedy.

1189.speaker: LYSANDER.
1189.line: Stay, gentle Helena; hear my excuse;

1190.speaker: LYSANDER.
1190.line: My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!

1192.speaker: HERMIA.
1192.line: Sweet, do not scorn her so.

1193.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1193.line: If she cannot entreat, I can compel.

1194.speaker: LYSANDER.
1194.line: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat;

1195.speaker: LYSANDER.
1195.line: Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.

1196.speaker: LYSANDER.
1196.line: Helen, I love thee, by my life I do;

1197.speaker: LYSANDER.
1197.line: I swear by that which I will lose for thee

1198.speaker: LYSANDER.
1198.line: To prove him false that says I love thee not.

1199.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1199.line: I say I love thee more than he can do.

1200.speaker: LYSANDER.
1200.line: If thou say so, withdraw, and prove it too.

1205.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1205.line: Seem to break loose. Take on as you would follow,

1206.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1206.line: But yet come not. You are a tame man, go!

1207.speaker: LYSANDER.
1207.line: Hang off, thou cat, thou burr! Vile thing, let loose,

1208.speaker: LYSANDER.
1208.line: Or I will shake thee from me like a serpent.

1209.speaker: HERMIA.
1209.line: Why are you grown so rude? What change is this,

1211.speaker: LYSANDER.
1211.line: Thy love? Out, tawny Tartar, out!

1212.speaker: LYSANDER.
1212.line: Out, loathèd medicine! O hated potion, hence!

1214.speaker: HELENA.
1214.line: Yes, sooth, and so do you.

1215.speaker: LYSANDER.
1215.line: Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.

1216.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1216.line: I would I had your bond; for I perceive

1217.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
1217.line: A weak bond holds you; I’ll not trust your word.

1218.speaker: LYSANDER.
1218.line: What, should I hurt her, strike her, kill her dead?

1219.speaker: LYSANDER.
1219.line: Although I hate her, I’ll not harm her so.

1220.speaker: HERMIA.
1220.line: What, can you do me greater harm than hate?

1221.speaker: HERMIA.
1221.line: Hate me? Wherefore? O me! what news, my love?

1222.speaker: HERMIA.
1222.line: Am not I Hermia? Are not you Lysander?

1223.speaker: HERMIA.
1223.line: I am as fair now as I was erewhile.

1224.speaker: HERMIA.
1224.line: Since night you lov’d me; yet since night you left me.

1225.speaker: HERMIA.
1225.line: Why then, you left me—O, the gods forbid!—

1228.speaker: LYSANDER.
1228.line: And never did desire to see thee more.

1229.speaker: LYSANDER.
1229.line: Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt;

1230.speaker: LYSANDER.
1230.line: Be certain, nothing truer; ’tis no jest

1231.speaker: LYSANDER.
1231.line: That I do hate thee and love Helena.

1232.speaker: HERMIA.
1232.line: O me! You juggler! You cankerblossom!

1233.speaker: HERMIA.
1233.line: You thief of love! What! have you come by night

1234.speaker: HERMIA.
1234.line: And stol’n my love’s heart from him?

1236.speaker: HELENA.
1236.line: Have you no modesty, no maiden shame,

1237.speaker: HELENA.
1237.line: No touch of bashfulness? What, will you tear

1238.speaker: HELENA.
1238.line: Impatient answers from my gentle tongue?

1239.speaker: HELENA.
1239.line: Fie, fie, you counterfeit, you puppet, you!

1240.speaker: HERMIA.
1240.line: Puppet! Why so? Ay, that way goes the game.

1241.speaker: HERMIA.
1241.line: Now I perceive that she hath made compare

1242.speaker: HERMIA.
1242.line: Between our statures; she hath urg’d her height;

1243.speaker: HERMIA.
1243.line: And with her personage, her tall personage,

1244.speaker: HERMIA.
1244.line: Her height, forsooth, she hath prevail’d with him.

1245.speaker: HERMIA.
1245.line: And are you grown so high in his esteem

1246.speaker: HERMIA.
1246.line: Because I am so dwarfish and so low?

1247.speaker: HERMIA.
1247.line: How low am I, thou painted maypole? Speak,

1248.speaker: HERMIA.
1248.line: How low am I? I am not yet so low

1249.speaker: HERMIA.
